title: Axa completes £2.8bn deal to protect pensions from risk of longer lives
text:

Sun, Jul 12, 2015, 21:27 BST - UK Markets closed Axa completes £2.8bn deal to protect pensions from risk of longer lives By Christopher Williams | Telegraph – 27 minutes ago +0.92 
Half of liabilities of final salary scheme transferred to US reinsurer in latest longevity swap 
The trustees of the Axa (Paris: FR0000120628 - news ) pension scheme have offloaded some of the risk that its members will live longer than expected in a £2.8bn longevity swap deal with Reinsurance Group of America. 
The agreement covers around half the liabilities of Axa final salary scheme, which closed to new members two years ago. 
The trustees said the move would provide 11,000 members of the scheme with additional security as it means their pension payments will continue to be made if more live longer and a deficit grows. Axa already has a multibillion-pound black hole in its pension fund. 
Stephen Yandle, chairman of Axa UK Pension Trustees said: “This is a very positive step in providing additional security of members’ pensions.” 
There will be no impact on payments as a result of the deal, he added. 
The longevity swap means the trustees will pay Reinsurance Group of America an annual premium based on a model of how long scheme members are expected to live. The US company will then pay pensions, suffering the impact if the calculations underestimate life spans. 
Charles Cowling of JLT Employee Benefits said: "We will see the number of longevity swap deals increase significantly. An insurer taking on the liabilities of a pension fund is a weight off the mind of many corporates. 
“Rising deficits and liabilities are a major drag on the sponsoring company of a scheme and we're beginning to see their impacts being reflected in share prices. A proactive approach to reducing pension risk is now a well-established route for companies and BT, Aviva (Other OTC: AIVAF - news ) and Scottish Power have all been recent high profile examples of this type of transaction.”
